page.title: 02TRADITIONAL PEAT CUTTING
page.content: To cut peat in the traditional manner is a long back-breaking process. First you must find a suitable peat bank. After that you must flay it, flaying is taking the heather off the top of the peat. You can then cut the peats either with a spade or a tusker. A tusker is a blade with a handle and a small piece of wood for your foot. The peat should be roughly rectagonal and about 5cms. wide, 22cms. high and 12cms. broad. Two people usually work together cutting peats, one to cut the other to take the cut peats and build them into a shore which is like a wall with holes in it to allow the peat to dry. After about three or four weeks the peat must be turned to allow the other side to dry. Then after another three or four weeks they can be taken down from the hill and used over the winter
